content.description: Probably use a rope. Not a pad.
content.protection: Top Rope, or LOTS of bouldering pads.
content.location: This is the left side of the tall line right of the Triple wall.

content.description: The sit start of "Short sighted." You need the vision to be able to find and want to attempt such a donkey line. Start on the good rail below the start of "short sighted", the opposing block is on but only for the first moves. Avoid using this up high.
content.location: Sit start extension of Short Sighted

content.description: There isn't really a crux on this one, other than the top.
content.location: About 5 minutes up trail from the Gorge Parking Lot.

content.description: This two move nonsense line is probably one you want to avoid but if you insist on doing it, start on the sloping arete and a hand hold that will consistently confuse and frustrate. Hit the good crimp below the roof and give a little hop to the dirty juggy top, mantle up on the dirt and leaves. Have fun...
content.location: Directly climbers right of "The Vision"

content.description: Traverse along the base of the roof, is it a hand-foot match? Start in two forever crumbling holds near the right center of the roof. Stay low? Stay high? Enjoy figuring it out...
content.location: The route is the first roof boulder you will come to from the Gorge Parking area.

content.description:
A little boulder problem. 

  Latitude: 41° 7' 12.71" N   Longitude: 81° 29' 29.73" W
Only use the right crack, hard up top.
content.location: See photo, right line.

content.description: Begin up Triple Right and finish on Triple Left, avoiding the top crux of Triple Right.
content.location: See Photo, Climbers left of the tall 50' wall.

content.description:
Rock is wet after rain. 

  Latitude: 41° 7' 14.43" N   Longitude: 81° 29' 25.23" W
Good jamming, leads to a ledge, down-climb or drop from ledge. Surprisingly great rock quality.
content.location: The route is the left crack of the two cracks, see photo.

content.description: The crux is a small crimp rail at 3/4 height. If you fall here, you are falling to a ledge 10' down or the depths about a 25-30' fall. It would be wise to brush the route and suss it on TR first...
content.protection: 1 pad, a great spotter and probably a rope.
content.location: The route is a short walk from the Front St Glens trail entrance, continue down the path and when you can break right, the route is behind Hibachi near the top of the hill.

content.description:
The whole route is relatively difficult, the difficulty varies with weather as all things in Ohio. You will need to implore some masochistic tendencies to top this route out. This is more of a grovel than trying to storm the capitol, donate some skin to send the route. This route has many nuances, culminating in a tough struggle fest top out. 

 Avoid the good foot rail below following your feet along the rail as well as the face you climb up for capitol grovel.
content.location: Start on the left side of the capitol grovel boulder, far back on the flatter portion of the sloper.

content.description: Rock quality is good, delicate moves about the arete. Fun climbing all and all.
content.location: This found by the graffiti at the base of the route, look for the K-W at the base of the route (left side of the arete). Look for the obvious chock-stone as seen in the photo on the right side of the arete. Update: The K+W is no longer there.

content.description: You need the vision to be able to find and want to attempt such a donkey line. This definitely is not the best line, but it is worth doing if you are in the area. Start on a good right hand and blocky split crimp for the left, use some heel trickery slap your way up to a good hold and finish up.
content.location: The next block climbers right of "George in the Gorge."

content.description: A little scary towards the top, start the same as I'll be at the bottom but instead of making the high reach to the sloping hold up high bust out left to the savior jugs. Either piano your hands or make a very large reach out to the jugs, and save yourself from a scary committing top.
content.protection: A few pads and a spotter or two.
content.location: See photo, just before slingblade. left of the wide downclimb crack.

content.description: Fun problem start on a ledge and make a large lock off move to a good crimp rail, match the rail and finish on the jugs up top. River Run is the left line.
content.location: The boulder is along the riverside, you access it off of a flat rock that protrudes into the river itself. Walk off top. Easier to approach from Front St. walk climbers right down to the river.

content.description: This is an open project, starting on the same holds as "Capitol Grovel, but trending out right using slimpers and slopers. Trend right along horrible holds to a sloping bowl and get some struggle going for the finish. There is not a single easy move on this. The line will likely be the hardest line in Northeast Ohio. Without question harder than V10.
content.location: Same as Capitol Grovel, trend right up to the sloping bowl and top left of the chopped vine.

content.description: Great line a tad more thuggy than its twin "Pop my heels on." Wear those pumps proud!
content.location: CLimbers left of LKLoTL, this route on "Pop my heels on" sharing the same start, only using the initial crimp then sailing out left to some good holds, from here gun to the finish jugs.

content.description: Surprisingly good rock, the starting hands will need brushed but other than that this is a great little warm up.
content.location: Climbers left of LKLoTL, this route begins on a corner jug and goes out to a crack. Top the route where the crack finishes on jugs.

content.description: A pristine route through and through, the climbing is relentlessly delicate. The crux is low but the entire route will keep you guessing on the send.
content.protection: Two pads or more as well as a spotter. This route could go on gear also.
content.location: About a 5 minute approach from the Gorge parking lot. The climb is climbers right of the wide crack, on the finest line of rock. There is a thin scar of a crack that is very obvious.

content.description: Start on the same holds as Typical Boulder beta, trend right and out of the roof along the right side. After the start hope your foot sticks and you're accurate on your bumps, otherwise the ground for you. Once you get established on the right of the roof continue up the sandy dirty ledges to the top.
content.location: First overhang in the park.

content.description: Right line. The route shares the same start with "Rivers Run" from here chug out right through a bad slope rail or a very large committing move to a crimp follow this to the top right corner.
content.protection: A bouldering pad and spotter, once you near the top you may have a bad fall (into the river.)
content.location: Same as "Rivers Run."

content.description:
Boulder traverse 

  Latitude: 41° 7' 12.61" N   Longitude: 81° 29' 28.362" W

climbs.name: Last king line on the left

content.description: Start on the right side of the short cave in a sharp left hand and a small crimp for your right hand. Make a big move out to a good hold, hold the barn door, match and move to the finish.
content.location: Start on right end of cave, just before the cave peters out

content.description:
Rock is a little wet after rain. 

  Latitude: 41° 7' 14.96" N   Longitude: 81° 29' 25.638" W
Quite a good route with a very committing top section, either deadpoint or use some slimps to gain the higher rail from the midpoint of the two good holds in the center.
content.protection: a few pads and a spotter.
content.location: Directly left of slingblade. The climbing is quite good on this line! Make sure you have a heads up spotter for this line.

content.description: After brushing the glossy iron sloping rail you'll wonder how this gets a V3 grade, trust me, this feels easier when you are hanging on the holds. Start low left on the rail trend up with heels and toes to a final jug.  Top out into a mouthful of dirt with a mantle over to the left for the full experience.
content.location: This is climbers right about 10 feet from the Capitol Grovel boulder, give it brush and send. Very fun little hidden gem.

content.description:
Rock is wet after rain. 

  Latitude: 41° 7' 13.96" N   Longitude: 81° 29' 27.012" W

Not yet climbed.  Pretty dry even with rain. 

  Latitude: 41° 7' 15.94" N   Longitude: 81° 29' 26.052" W

Not yet climbed. 

  Latitude: 41° 7' 12.6" N   Longitude: 81° 29' 29.268" W

Start low on a good rail beneath the right side of the roof. Make a move to a good rail in the roof out to a slopey hold on the face and throw to the ledge. Most times dreidels are made of clay, some are made of sharp rock to repel the pretenders.
content.protection: single pad, spotter and not frail skin.
content.location: Left side of roof

content.description: The crux is lower, pulling longer moves on sharp crimps, the climb eases as you continue higher, don't blow the moves up top. The rock quality is terrific on this one.
content.location: The route is 5 minutes from the gorge parking lot and has a notable K+W at the base (left).

content.description: Really great boulder problem, especially for Northeast Ohio, one of the only stand alone boulders with a problem in the Cuyahoga Gorge. Start beneath the kickback of the boulder on the right side in some very good pockets. Make a few moves on pockets to a big move to a rail, then grovel your way up the storm of the hill.
content.protection: A pad or two and a spotter.
content.location: On the left side of glens trail when approaching from the gorge, a stand alone boulder with some great pockets.

content.description:
Glens is located in Cuyahoga Falls, OH and has plenty of rock ledges. The rock is sandstone. Almost all of the ledges are south-east facing and thus in many areas are quite dry and without any mosses / plant growth.  However, in the winter the rock is typically dryer within Cuyahoga Falls Gorge area (see MP listing).   

  There are no official camping spots in the park and no fees to enter. Alcoholic beverages of any kind are forbidden in the park. Do not bring them for any reason.  There are zero routes officially marked.   

  Please do not touch rocks with moss or lichens on it. These are important for the wildlife and need to be protected. Stick to areas that are dry and without growth and directly adjacent to the path (walking off the path is not permitted).  This park is great for hiking to see the rocks and many rock overhangs. It has two pretty nice waterfalls. Also, the "Highbridge Glens" trail has some spectacular views of the river. The Cuyahoga River runs through it and if you are ambitious, you can take a kayak down there and ride the river.  

  The "Highbridge Glens" trail has a South-East facing rock wall over most of the path that gets a lot of sun (more in the summer than winter). The Glens trail runs about 0.5 miles and most of it has a 20 - 50 foot high rock face. There are plenty of traverse options. There are also numerous other places to see nice rock faces in the park (See Cuyahoga Falls Gorge). Choose your own adventure and tread lightly.  

  Glens has a main entrance area that can be found easily on Google (see Getting There for information). There is another entrance that is a bit hidden on the North-east end of the trail. 

  The Highbridge Glens trail has some interesting history that you can read about here: 

blogs.uakron.edu/cap/high-b…

  Nearby places to eat / drink:    Before or after you hike, make a visit to Blue Door Cafe and Bakery located at 1970 State Rd., Cuyahoga Falls, OH. This is one of the best cafes in a 100 mile radius of the area! Super fresh made bread and great food, but check hours to make sure they are open bluedoorcafebakery.com. You may also like to try another nearby cafe (walkable distance from Gorge, fluryscafe.com/). This has some nice breakfast and early afternoon lunch. Also, "The Office", "Craft Beer Bar" near downtown Cuyahoga Falls are nice for an after hike dinner / beer. Burntwood Tavern in Downtown Cuyahoga Falls has an awesome patio overlooking the Cuyahoga River and great craft beers to choose from.
